title: A brief account of a tour through some parts of Scotland
author: Hunter, Robert
snippet: TheCastle stands at the top, and the Palace ofHolyrood house at the bottom. St. Giles'Church, Avhich contains three places of Avorship : — the Parliament house and buildingsconnected with it, the Advocates' Library,and County Buildings, are on the left in goingup towards the Castle. The Church is themost conspicuous object, and gives the streeta noble appearance.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: In 1715, it was converted into barracks for the Hanoverian soldiers, and in 1746, it was blown up by the trooj^s of Prince Charles Stuart, and not a vestige of it now remains. On its site a castellated building has been erected, from a design by Mr. Burn, architect, which serves as the Court House and County Buildings. On the north side of the town, near the mouth of the river, Cromwell erected a sort at an expense of £80,000, which was demolished at the Restoration, but a considerable  part of the rampart still remains.

title: Early Travellers in Scotland. Edited by P. Hume Brown. [With maps.]
author: Brown, Peter Hume.
snippet: 1 The site of the Gowrie House, of which nothing now remains, is occupiedby the County Buildings.
